poem:
### Coastal Lament

Battered seas,
call of gulls,  
youth edged  
by receding tides.

House of Wingz—  
echoes, whispers  
of dreams  
adrift.

Tamsin speaks,  
a future  
bleached by  
salt, swept  
by yearning—  
nothing here  
but silence,  
promise vague  
as a morning mist.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Thursday briefing: Why young people fear ‘there’s nothing here for us’ in England’s coastal towns Good morning. A few weeks ago, 18-year-old Tamsin Jarman-Smith, born and raised in a small town just outside Blackpool, sat on a battered sofa at House of Wingz, a community youth organisation tucked down an alleyway a few streets from the beach, and explained what it felt like to be a young person growing up in a coastal town. “I’m". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
